Notes: Colombian variant of 'gripe'. Used for both common cold and flu. Very common expression in everyday conversation.
Distinctly Colombian way to say you're feeling unwell. More informal than 'enfermo/a'. Very commonly used in daily conversation.

Back (EN): I have the flu/cold (I'm sick with flu)
Notes: Adjective form describing someone who has gripa. Same as 'agripado/a'. Informal but widely understood.
Noun form of 'maluco'. Expresses general unwellness or feeling bad. Very Colombian expression.

Back (EN): I have a headache / My head hurts
Notes: Standard expression for headache. Pattern extends to other body parts (me duele el estómago, me duele la espalda).
Reply: Toma una pastilla para el dolor.

Notes: Direct way to express having a fever. Essential health vocabulary.
Reply: Debes ir al médico si sigue alta.

Notes: Common symptom expression. 'Garganta' is throat.
Diminutive form suggesting you're not too ill but want sympathy. Softens the statement.
General way to express not feeling good without specifying symptoms. Polite and common.
Expresses dizziness or vertigo. Important symptom to communicate.
Expresses feeling sick to your stomach, wanting to vomit.

Back (EN): I have a stomach ache / My stomach hurts
Notes: Common pain expression for stomach area. Can also say 'me duele la barriga/panza' informally.
Alternative: Tengo dolor de estómago, Me duele la panza

Notes: Direct medical term. Important for communicating digestive issues.
Colorful Colombian slang for diarrhea. Usually used with 'tener'. More informal than 'diarrea'.
Reply: ¡Ay no! Espero que te mejores pronto.

Notes: Medical term for constipation. Important digestive health vocabulary.
Reply: Come más fibra y toma agua.

Notes: Simple, direct expression for coughing. Common cold/flu symptom.
Expresses physical weakness or lack of energy. Also used for laziness in other contexts.
Alternative: Me siento débil, No tengo energía

Notes: Formal term for having a cold (resfriado). Less common in Colombia than 'gripa'.
In Colombia, 'droguería' and 'farmacia' both mean pharmacy. 'Droguería' is more commonly used.
General term for medication in pill form. 'Pastillas' is very common.
Important phrase for getting prescription medications at the pharmacy.
Reply: El doctor te la puede dar.

Back (EN): Can you give me something for the pain?
Notes: Common pharmacy request. 'Algo para...' pattern useful for requesting remedies.
Specific medication request. 'Analgésico' is painkiller/pain reliever.
'Jarabe' is syrup. Common medication form for coughs and colds.
Standard phrase for medical appointment. 'Cita médica' or 'cita con el médico'.
Simple, direct way to say you're visiting the doctor.
Alternative: Voy a la consulta, Voy donde el doctor

Notes: Very Colombian way to ask for bathroom. 'Prestar' literally means 'to lend' but used for bathroom requests.
Alternative: ¿Puedo usar el baño? ¿Dónde está el baño?
Reply: Claro, es la primera puerta a la derecha.

Back (EN): I'm going to take a shower/bath
Notes: 'Bañarse' means to bathe. Very common daily hygiene expression.
Alternative: Me voy a duchar, Voy a tomar una ducha
Reply: ¿Ya te vas a bañar? El agua está caliente.

Back (EN): I'm going to brush my teeth
Notes: Literally 'wash my teeth'. Also 'cepillarme los dientes' (brush my teeth).
Colombian slang for body odor, especially from armpits. Informal but commonly understood.
Colombian term for foot odor. Used with 'tener'. Informal and often humorous.
Informal term for stomach/belly. More colloquial than 'estómago'. Common with children.
Alternative: Me duele el estómago, Me duele la panza

Notes: Common pain complaint. 'Espalda' is back.
Ear pain expression. 'Oído' is ear (inner ear). Also 'oreja' for outer ear.
Reply: Puede ser una infección, ve al médico.

Notes: Tooth pain expression. 'Muela' is molar/tooth.
Alternative: Me duele la muela, Me duele un diente

Notes: Euphemistic way to say urinate. Like English 'number one'. Family-friendly.
Reply: Voy a hacer del uno rapidito.

Notes: Euphemistic way to say defecate. Like English 'number two'. Family-friendly.
Reply: Voy a hacer del dos, ya vuelvo.

Notes: Colombian slang for hangover. Very common after drinking alcohol.
Strong expression of feeling very unwell. More intense than 'me siento mal'.
Alternative: Me siento muy mal, Me siento pésimo

Notes: Formal, elegant way to say you're sick. More polite than 'enfermo'.
Alternative: Estoy enfermo/a, No me siento bien

Back (EN): What happened to you? / What's wrong?
Notes: Common way to ask what's wrong with someone who looks unwell.
Reply: Nada grave, solo un poco cansado.

Notes: Standard way to ask about someone's wellbeing or health condition.
Reply: Me siento un poco mejor, gracias.

Notes: Direct expression for needing to vomit. Also 'voy a devolver' in some regions.
Alternative: Tengo ganas de vomitar, Voy a devolver

Notes: Symptom of fever or illness. 'Escalofríos' means chills/shivers.
Reply: Abrígate bien y toma algo caliente.

Notes: 'Moretón' is bruise. Common injury vocabulary.
Alternative: Me salió un morado, Tengo un morado

Notes: Simple past tense of 'cortarse'. Common injury expression.
'Curita' is band-aid in many Latin American countries. Diminutive of 'cura' (cure).
Alternative: Necesito una venda, Necesito un apósito

Notes: Allergy expression. Important for medical situations.
Important health/medical state. 'Embarazada' is pregnant (false friend for English speakers).
Alternative: Estoy en embarazo, Voy a tener un bebé

Notes: Common complaint. 'Picar' means to sting/bite for insects.
Alternative: Me picó un zancudo (more common in Colombia)
